title: 106_hr605
content: The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service on the Court in accordance with specific requirements. Retired judges must provide written notice of their availability and willingness to be recalled, which is irrevocable. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service on the Court. A retired judge is defined as a judge who retires from the Court under specific sections, and a recall-eligible retired judge is one who has provided notice of availability. The chief judge may recall a recall-eligible retired judge for a period not exceeding 90 days in a calendar year. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows retired judges to be recalled for further service on the Court for up to 90 days in a calendar year. If a recall-eligible retired judge declines to perform the service to which recalled, they may be removed from the status of a recall-eligible judge. Additionally, a recall-eligible retired judge who becomes permanently disabled and unable to perform further service on the court will be removed from the status of a recall-eligible judge. A retired judge recalled for further service on the Court may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled judge varies based on retirement status. A retired judge recalled for further service on the Court may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled judge varies based on retirement status, with the amount adjusted by the judge's annuity under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5. If a judge retired under these chapters, they are considered a reemployed annuitant under that chapter when recalled. This section does not affect the right of a retired judge to serve as a reemployed annuitant in accordance with title 5. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating service. Fractional parts of a year less than 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is amended to specify the retired pay for recall-eligible retired judges and those who did not provide notice of availability for service in a recalled status. The retired pay for recall-eligible retired judges is specified in Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code. The pay rate is based on the judge's status at the time of retirement or removal from recall status. Cost-of-living adjustments apply only to retired pay computed under specific subsections. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges are limited to specific subsections to prevent their pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for active judges. Adjustments for retired chief judges are capped at the chief judge's pay rate, while adjustments for other retired judges are limited to the rate for judges of the court. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges are limited to prevent their pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for active judges. Retired or retainer pay for military members who become judges of the court is suspended during active service on the court but resumes without reduction upon retirement. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. A new section is added to Chapter 72 of title 38, United States Code, stating that retired judges forfeit their retired pay if they represent clients in claims related to veterans' benefits against the United States or its agencies. SEC. 7. EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY FOR CURRENT JUDGES TO PROVIDE STAGGERED TERMS. Retirement authorized for eligible judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims with specific criteria including years of service and age. If multiple judges are eligible, the one with the most seniority will retire. In accordance with subsection (d), the most senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims eligible to retire in that year must provide written notice of retirement by April 1, except for 1999 where the deadline is November 1 or 15 days after the enactment of the Act. The retirement date must be specified and the notice is irrevocable. The retirement date must be specified in accordance with subsection (e) and the notice provided is irrevocable. A judge eligible to retire shall be retired during the fiscal year in which notice is given, not earlier than 90 days after the notice is provided. The retired judge will be considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code, except for specific provisions outlined in subsection (g) regarding the rate of retired pay. The rate of retired pay for a judge retiring in accordance with this section is determined by a specific formula based on years of service and age. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to certain provisions outlined in the law. An adjustment in annuities for retired judges under civil service retirement laws applies to recall-eligible retired judges under title 38. The term 'present value' now includes actuarial determinations for payments from the retirement fund.
